Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module introduces students to modern genetics and developmental biology at an introductory level. Using examples taken from across the biosciences and medicine, students will develop their understanding of the inheritance of genetic traits, how mutation can lead to disease and the molecular techniques used to study genes. They will also be introduced to development from meiosis and germ cell formation through to organogenesis, emphasising both the underlying genetic and molecular mechanisms involved and the embryological processes. Students will explore current advances in both fields including current and potential use of gene editing techniques and stem cells in therapeutics, and will consider the ethical implications of these advances.
The module is taught through a combination of lectures and workshops incorporating problem solving and discussion, with an emphasis on an appreciation of the techniques and experimental evidence underpinning the material. Assessment is by a combination of a written examination and a group ethics poster presentation.
Educational Aims
1) To develop students’ knowledge of the genetic basis of heredity and the application of modern genetic techniques across biology and medicine.

2) To develop knowledge and understanding of the major events that comprise embryogenesis and of the genetic and cell-biological mechanisms that underpin developmental events.

3) To enable students to appreciate the ethical issues surrounding modern genetic technology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module introduces students to modern genetics and developmental biology at an introductory level. Using examples taken from across the biosciences and medicine, students will develop their understanding of the inheritance of genetic traits, how mutation can lead to disease and the molecular techniques used to study genes. They will also be introduced to development from meiosis and germ cell formation through to organogenesis, emphasising both the underlying genetic and molecular mechanisms involved and the embryological processes. Students will explore current advances in both fields including current and potential use of gene editing techniques and stem cells in therapeutics, and will consider the ethical implications of these advances.
The module is taught through a combination of lectures and workshops incorporating problem solving and discussion, with an emphasis on an appreciation of the techniques and experimental evidence underpinning the material. Assessment is by a combination of a written examination and a group ethics poster presentation.
Outline Syllabus
• Germ cells and meiosis/gene segregation
• Fertilisation
• Mendelian genetics
• Non-mendelian genetics
• Mutation at the molecular level
• Identifying the gene(s) which underlie a trait/condition
• Sequencing technology
• Studying genes: Cloning; GMOs; gene editing
• Therapies for genetic disease:
• Early development/differentiation
• Stem cells
• Developmental principles/body plans
• Gastrulation and formation of the germ layers
• Organogenesis
• Ethics
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and workshop content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 – Asynchronous Lecture Material (24 hours)
Description: Lectures to introduce key concepts

Teaching Method 2 – Online (114 hours)
Description: Materials providing an opportunity for reflective and self-directed learning. These are materials that students will be encouraged to use to consolidate their learning and prepare for lectures/workshops as part of their self-directed learning hours

Teaching Method 3 – Workshop (6 hours Live synchronous sessions - weekly)
Description: Problem solving workshops, ethical debate

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students conduct an ethical debate for example which builds group working, self-confidence and critical thinking.

Assessment 1: Group Coursework. In groups, students to be assigned an ethical topic relating to Genetics/Development topical scenario. Students to implement subject knowledge and ethical debate to create well rounded Students will work as a group to to create a single digital poster. Marked using NO MORE MARKING, comparative online marking tool. Both students and staff would mark the posters. 75% of the mark (30%) would come from the staff mark - rubric would be supplied.
25% of the mark (10%) would come from the student’s mark - rubric supplied to the students asking them to provide a mark out of 10 for the poster.
Students also use online peer assessment system (‘Buddy check’) which will be employed to allow group members to assess their own and their team members’ contribution during the production of the poster. Buddy Check produces a weighting factor based on students’ assessment of each other’s contribution on a 0-5 scale. The calculated weighting factors will be used to weight the group poster mark and produce an individual mark for each student to allow mark allocation and fairness based on the group engagement & teamwork. [LO5; S1-4]

Assessment 2: Invigilated exam [LO 1-5; S2-3]

Marks for the two assessments will be aggregated. The overall pass mark for the module will be 40%

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

No
Notes
The new 15 credit module LIFE128 replaces two 15 credit modules LIFE108 Developmental Biology and LIFE114 Applied Genetic and Molecular Technologies’. Evidence suggests that approximately 50% of students in the School of Life Sciences, (B110, C130, B120, B210 and C700; ~200 students) are progressing through their degrees with a limited knowledge of genetics, molecular and developmental biology and are not progressing beyond their pre-university understanding. Students reading their life sciences degrees follow a common first semester. After Christmas, the module choices for each programme become more varied and so students are able to choose their preferences, from ‘programme relevant’ optional modules. Students on the Biological and Medical sciences programme (C130) must currently choose module groupings from two pathways, biomedical or biomolecular. This choice can result in students lacking the required knowledge base, which they may require, as they progress through their studies. Furthermore, students on the “biomedical programmes, Anatomy and Human Biology, Biochemistry, C130, Human Physiology and Pharmacology” are currently taking level 6 modules and projects which have a molecular basis, which they are ill prepared for. Therefore, combining LIFE108 and LIFE114 ensures that our Life Sciences students are better equipped for their future studies, across a range of disciplines. A secondary benefit to the School would be a reduction in the number of modules.

Please note, this module is not a pre-requisite for level 6 research projects. However, this module is required for level 5 modules (LIFE205 and LIFE226) which may be used by the school in the project allocation process.

This new module will allow learners (especially those in the “Biomedical” programmes, almost half of the School of Life Science’s entry) the opportunity to experience the variety of disciplines in the Life Sciences before having to make pathway choices. Crucially, this proposal will defer the point at which module choices are made from the end of semester 1 to the end of semester 2, thus enabling learners to make informed decisions on their academic pathways and subsequent honours degree exit route. These routes include, Biochemistry, Biological Sciences, C130, Genetics, Human Physiology and Pharmacology.

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Recognise how germ cell development, meiosis and molecular mechanisms lead to variation in offspring and be able to interpret patterns of inheritance.
 LO2 Choose and know how to apply relevant molecular technologies to study genes, and at an introductory level to create genetically modified organisms and treat genetic disease.
 LO3 Identify the fundamental mechanisms that regulate development and the events that lead to germ layer formation and organogenesis.
 LO4 Identify the experimental models and methods used to investigate the mechanisms that regulate development.
 LO5 Identify the general properties of stem cells, their role in development and their therapeutic potential.
 LO6 Discuss the ethical issues associated with developments in genetics, development and stem cell therapies.

HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module introduces students to modern genetics and developmental biology at an introductory level. Using examples taken from across the biosciences and medicine, students will develop their understanding of the inheritance of genetic traits, how mutation can lead to disease and the molecular techniques used to study genes. They will also be introduced to development from meiosis and germ cell formation through to organogenesis, emphasising both the underlying genetic and molecular mechanisms involved and the embryological processes. Students will explore current advances in both fields including current and potential use of gene editing techniques and stem cells in therapeutics, and will consider the ethical implications of these advances.
The module is taught through a combination of lectures and workshops incorporating problem solving and discussion, with an emphasis on an appreciation of the techniques and experimental evidence underpinning the material. Assessment is by a combination of a written examination and a group ethics poster presentation.
Educational Aims
1) To develop students’ knowledge of the genetic basis of heredity and the application of modern genetic techniques across biology and medicine.

2) To develop knowledge and understanding of the major events that comprise embryogenesis and of the genetic and cell-biological mechanisms that underpin developmental events.

3) To enable students to appreciate the ethical issues surrounding modern genetic technology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module introduces students to modern genetics and developmental biology at an introductory level. Using examples taken from across the biosciences and medicine, students will develop their understanding of the inheritance of genetic traits, how mutation can lead to disease and the molecular techniques used to study genes. They will also be introduced to development from meiosis and germ cell formation through to organogenesis, emphasising both the underlying genetic and molecular mechanisms involved and the embryological processes. Students will explore current advances in both fields including current and potential use of gene editing techniques and stem cells in therapeutics, and will consider the ethical implications of these advances.
The module is taught through a combination of lectures and workshops incorporating problem solving and discussion, with an emphasis on an appreciation of the techniques and experimental evidence underpinning the material. Assessment is by a combination of a written examination and a group ethics poster presentation.
Outline Syllabus
• Germ cells and meiosis/gene segregation
• Fertilisation
• Mendelian genetics
• Non-mendelian genetics
• Mutation at the molecular level
• Identifying the gene(s) which underlie a trait/condition
• Sequencing technology
• Studying genes: Cloning; GMOs; gene editing
• Therapies for genetic disease:
• Early development/differentiation
• Stem cells
• Developmental principles/body plans
• Gastrulation and formation of the germ layers
• Organogenesis
• Ethics
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and workshop content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 – Asynchronous Lecture Material (24 hours)
Description: Lectures to introduce key concepts

Teaching Method 2 – Online (114 hours)
Description: Materials providing an opportunity for reflective and self-directed learning. These are materials that students will be encouraged to use to consolidate their learning and prepare for lectures/workshops as part of their self-directed learning hours

Teaching Method 3 – Workshop (6 hours Live synchronous sessions - weekly)
Description: Problem solving workshops, ethical debate

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students conduct an ethical debate for example which builds group working, self-confidence and critical thinking.

Assessment 1: Group Coursework. In groups, students to be assigned an ethical topic relating to Genetics/Development topical scenario. Students to implement subject knowledge and ethical debate to create well rounded Students will work as a group to to create a single digital poster. Marked using NO MORE MARKING, comparative online marking tool. Both students and staff would mark the posters. 75% of the mark (30%) would come from the staff mark - rubric would be supplied.
25% of the mark (10%) would come from the student’s mark - rubric supplied to the students asking them to provide a mark out of 10 for the poster.
Students also use online peer assessment system (‘Buddy check’) which will be employed to allow group members to assess their own and their team members’ contribution during the production of the poster. Buddy Check produces a weighting factor based on students’ assessment of each other’s contribution on a 0-5 scale. The calculated weighting factors will be used to weight the group poster mark and produce an individual mark for each student to allow mark allocation and fairness based on the group engagement & teamwork. [LO5; S1-4]

Assessment 2: Invigilated exam [LO 1-5; S2-3]

Marks for the two assessments will be aggregated. The overall pass mark for the module will be 40%

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Admin

Notes
The new 15 credit module LIFE128 replaces two 15 credit modules LIFE108 Developmental Biology and LIFE114 Applied Genetic and Molecular Technologies’. Evidence suggests that approximately 50% of students in the School of Life Sciences, (B110, C130, B120, B210 and C700; ~200 students) are progressing through their degrees with a limited knowledge of genetics, molecular and developmental biology and are not progressing beyond their pre-university understanding. Students reading their life sciences degrees follow a common first semester. After Christmas, the module choices for each programme become more varied and so students are able to choose their preferences, from ‘programme relevant’ optional modules. Students on the Biological and Medical sciences programme (C130) must currently choose module groupings from two pathways, biomedical or biomolecular. This choice can result in students lacking the required knowledge base, which they may require, as they progress through their studies. Furthermore, students on the “biomedical programmes, Anatomy and Human Biology, Biochemistry, C130, Human Physiology and Pharmacology” are currently taking level 6 modules and projects which have a molecular basis, which they are ill prepared for. Therefore, combining LIFE108 and LIFE114 ensures that our Life Sciences students are better equipped for their future studies, across a range of disciplines. A secondary benefit to the School would be a reduction in the number of modules.

Please note, this module is not a pre-requisite for level 6 research projects. However, this module is required for level 5 modules (LIFE205 and LIFE226) which may be used by the school in the project allocation process.

This new module will allow learners (especially those in the “Biomedical” programmes, almost half of the School of Life Science’s entry) the opportunity to experience the variety of disciplines in the Life Sciences before having to make pathway choices. Crucially, this proposal will defer the point at which module choices are made from the end of semester 1 to the end of semester 2, thus enabling learners to make informed decisions on their academic pathways and subsequent honours degree exit route. These routes include, Biochemistry, Biological Sciences, C130, Genetics, Human Physiology and Pharmacology.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Recognise how germ cell development, meiosis and molecular mechanisms lead to variation in offspring and be able to interpret patterns of inheritance.
 LO2 Choose and know how to apply relevant molecular technologies to study genes, and at an introductory level to create genetically modified organisms and treat genetic disease.
 LO3 Identify the fundamental mechanisms that regulate development and the events that lead to germ layer formation and organogenesis.
 LO4 Identify the experimental models and methods used to investigate the mechanisms that regulate development.
 LO5 Identify the general properties of stem cells, their role in development and their therapeutic potential.
 LO6 Discuss the ethical issues associated with developments in genetics, development and stem cell therapies.

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Effective Group working
 S2 Structure and communicate ideas effectively
 S3 Access and evaluate information
 S4 Evaluate own performance and working standards and those of others

Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and workshop content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 – Asynchronous Lecture Material (24 hours)
Description: Lectures to introduce key concepts

Teaching Method 2 – Online (114 hours)
Description: Materials providing an opportunity for reflective and self-directed learning. These are materials that students will be encouraged to use to consolidate their learning and prepare for lectures/workshops as part of their self-directed learning hours

Teaching Method 3 – Workshop (6 hours Live synchronous sessions - weekly)
Description: Problem solving workshops, ethical debate

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students conduct an ethical debate for example which builds group working, self-confidence and critical thinking.

Assessment 1: Group Coursework. In groups, students to be assigned an ethical topic relating to Genetics/Development topical scenario. Students to implement subject knowledge and ethical debate to create well rounded Students will work as a group to to create a single digital poster. Marked using NO MORE MARKING, comparative online marking tool. Both students and staff would mark the posters. 75% of the mark (30%) would come from the staff mark - rubric would be supplied.
25% of the mark (10%) would come from the student’s mark - rubric supplied to the students asking them to provide a mark out of 10 for the poster.
Students also use online peer assessment system (‘Buddy check’) which will be employed to allow group members to assess their own and their team members’ contribution during the production of the poster. Buddy Check produces a weighting factor based on students’ assessment of each other’s contribution on a 0-5 scale. The calculated weighting factors will be used to weight the group poster mark and produce an individual mark for each student to allow mark allocation and fairness based on the group engagement & teamwork. [LO5; S1-4]

Assessment 2: Invigilated exam [LO 1-5; S2-3]

Marks for the two assessments will be aggregated. The overall pass mark for the module will be 40%

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

Notes
The new 15 credit module LIFE128 replaces two 15 credit modules LIFE108 Developmental Biology and LIFE114 Applied Genetic and Molecular Technologies’. Evidence suggests that approximately 50% of students in the School of Life Sciences, (B110, C130, B120, B210 and C700; ~200 students) are progressing through their degrees with a limited knowledge of genetics, molecular and developmental biology and are not progressing beyond their pre-university understanding. Students reading their life sciences degrees follow a common first semester. After Christmas, the module choices for each programme become more varied and so students are able to choose their preferences, from ‘programme relevant’ optional modules. Students on the Biological and Medical sciences programme (C130) must currently choose module groupings from two pathways, biomedical or biomolecular. This choice can result in students lacking the required knowledge base, which they may require, as they progress through their studies. Furthermore, students on the “biomedical programmes, Anatomy and Human Biology, Biochemistry, C130, Human Physiology and Pharmacology” are currently taking level 6 modules and projects which have a molecular basis, which they are ill prepared for. Therefore, combining LIFE108 and LIFE114 ensures that our Life Sciences students are better equipped for their future studies, across a range of disciplines. A secondary benefit to the School would be a reduction in the number of modules.

Please note, this module is not a pre-requisite for level 6 research projects. However, this module is required for level 5 modules (LIFE205 and LIFE226) which may be used by the school in the project allocation process.

This new module will allow learners (especially those in the “Biomedical” programmes, almost half of the School of Life Science’s entry) the opportunity to experience the variety of disciplines in the Life Sciences before having to make pathway choices. Crucially, this proposal will defer the point at which module choices are made from the end of semester 1 to the end of semester 2, thus enabling learners to make informed decisions on their academic pathways and subsequent honours degree exit route. These routes include, Biochemistry, Biological Sciences, C130, Genetics, Human Physiology and Pharmacology.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Recognise how germ cell development, meiosis and molecular mechanisms lead to variation in offspring and be able to interpret patterns of inheritance.
 LO2 Choose and know how to apply relevant molecular technologies to study genes, and at an introductory level to create genetically modified organisms and treat genetic disease.
 LO3 Identify the fundamental mechanisms that regulate development and the events that lead to germ layer formation and organogenesis.
 LO4 Identify the experimental models and methods used to investigate the mechanisms that regulate development.
 LO5 Identify the general properties of stem cells, their role in development and their therapeutic potential.
 LO6 Discuss the ethical issues associated with developments in genetics, development and stem cell therapies.
